commander.name: Generalmajor Friedrich Weber
commander.previous_service: Promoted to Generalmajor on 1 January 1943 after arriving in Tunisia as Oberst in late December 1942

tanks.note: Infantry division - no organic tank units

anti_tank.note: Mixed AT gun inventory typical of Tunisia-deployed divisions. Older PaK 36 supplemented with more effective PaK 40.

anti_aircraft.note: Light AA defense only. Division relies on Luftwaffe air cover (limited by Allied air superiority).

soft_skin_vehicles.note: Mixed motorized/horse-drawn transport typical of infantry divisions. Significant use of captured Italian vehicles after January 1943 delivery to Tunisia.

armored_cars.note: Infantry division reconnaissance uses motorcycles and light vehicles, not armored cars

supply_logistics.supply_status: ADEQUATE - Division newly arrived Tunisia January 1943 with full initial equipment allocation. As campaign progresses Feb-March, fuel/ammunition shortages worsen due to Allied naval/air interdiction. By late March, chronic shortages affect operations.
notes: Division arrived Tunisia by ship from Naples, January 1943
Initial equipment state good, deteriorates through Q1
Allied air superiority disrupts supply lines from Sicily
Heavy fighting Feb-March reduces ammunition stocks
Surrender at Beja 8 May 1943 ends division history

weather_environment.terrain_type: Northern Tunisia mountains - Rugged mountainous terrain around Tunis. Kampfgruppe Krause (334th ID) defended mountain positions Feb-March. Terrain includes steep ridges, narrow valleys, limited roads.
notes: Division (Kampfgruppe Krause) defended northern Tunisian mountains
Heavy rains January-March create mud, limit mobility
Allied air superiority restricts daylight movement
Successfully defended 'Run for Tunis' January 1943 with 10. Panzer and Division von Manteuffel

subordinate_units.equipment: Regiment from XIII Wehrkreis (Nuremberg). Three battalions plus support companies.
subordinate_units.note: Lead elements arrived Bizerta late December 1942. Veteran recruits from Bavarian region.

subordinate_units.equipment: Regiment from XVII Wehrkreis (Vienna). Three battalions plus support companies.
subordinate_units.note: Austrian recruits. Full regiment arrived by 15 January 1943.

subordinate_units.equipment: Mountain regiment from XVIII Wehrkreis (Salzburg). Two mountain battalions, one MG company, one heavy company. 13th Company: Panzerj채ger (AT).
subordinate_units.note: Specialized mountain troops. Division's unusual composition: two infantry regiments + one mountain regiment.
Four battalions: three field artillery, one mixed light/heavy
Three companies. Mixed gun types reflect equipment availability Tunisia 1943.
Three companies: combat engineers, demolition, mine warfare. Critical for mountain defense.
Radio, telephone, and dispatch companies. Mountain terrain challenges communications.
Replacement training battalion. Absorbs stragglers, provides reinforcements to regiments.
Transport, maintenance, medical, veterinary, postal, administration companies.

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry division defending northern Tunisia mountain sector. Division formed November 1942 as 'Kriemhilde' unit, deployed Tunisia January 1943. Fought defensive operations Jan-March as Kampfgruppe Krause. Successfully helped defend Tunis in 'Run for Tunis' January 1943 alongside 10. Panzer and Division von Manteuffel. Surrendered Beja 8 May 1943.
special_capabilities: Successful defense Jan 1943 against Allied 'Run for Tunis'
known_issues: New division - formed November 1942, limited unit cohesion
Unusual composition: mix of infantry and mountain troops from three different Wehrkreise
No prior combat experience as division before Tunisia
Heavy losses Feb-March 1943 in mountain fighting
Allied air superiority limits movement and resupply
tactical_doctrine.defensive_strategy: Division assigned northern Tunisia mountain sector. Kampfgruppe Krause (core of 334th) remained continuously engaged Feb-March defending mountain positions. Rugged terrain favors defense but limits mobility. Division capitulated 8 May 1943 at Beja after months of attritional fighting.

historical_context.formation: Formed 25 November 1942 as 'Division Kriemhilde'. Three regiments drawn from three different Wehrkreise: 754/XIII (Nuremberg), 755/XVII (Vienna), 756/XVIII (Salzburg). Regiment 756 was mountain infantry, giving division unusual mixed composition.
historical_context.deployment_tunisia: Shipped from Naples to Tunisia January 1943. Lead elements (754th Regiment) arrived Bizerta late December 1942. Full division assembled by 15 January 1943. Assigned to 5. Panzerarmee.
historical_context.combat_operations: January 1943: Successfully defended Tunis in 'Run for Tunis' alongside 10. Panzer Division and Division von Manteuffel. February-March 1943: Kampfgruppe Krause (core of 334th) defended northern Tunisia mountains. Continuous heavy fighting. May 8, 1943: Surrendered to Allied forces at Beja.
historical_context.fate: Division destroyed in Tunisia surrender 8 May 1943. Reformed June 1943 in Bordeaux, southern France with same regimental numbers but entirely new personnel. Reformed division fought Italy 1943-1944, surrendered Norway May 1945.

scenario_suitability: Defense of Tunis - 'Run for Tunis' January 1943
wargaming_data.experience_level: Green (division newly formed November 1942, first combat Tunisia)
special_rules: Mountain infantry regiment (756th) gets terrain bonus in hills/mountains
Mixed composition: three regiments from different regions (Bavaria, Austria, Salzburg)
New division - no prior unit combat history before Tunisia
Allied air superiority: -1 to movement in daylight
Supply shortages worsen as Q1 progresses (fuel/ammo penalties late March)
historical_engagements: Defense of Tunis ('Run for Tunis') - January 1943
Northern Tunisia mountain defensive operations - February-March 1943
